choices.text: Allis tissue holding forcep
Babcock forceps
Cervical punch biopsy forcep
Pipelle’s endometrial biopsy forcep

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cervical punch biopsy forceps

  • This is a cervical punch biopsy forceps
  • It is used to take a biopsy from a cervical growth or suspicious area on the cervix
  • The biopsy is taken form the periphery of the cervical growth (Never from the center)

Other options: 

  • Allis Foceps: It is used to hold tough structures 

 

  • Babcock Forceps: It is an atraumatic forceps and is used to hold delicate structures like the fallopian tube

 

  • Endometrial aspiration cannula: It is a thin cannula which is introduced through the cervix to take an endometrial sample. It does 

Educational Objective:

  • Any growth on the cervix should be biopsied using a punch biopsy forceps

Ref: Page no 605, DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Ultrasound
CT scan
MRI
Imaging modalities should not be used for staging or management

questions.text: A 56 year old parous lady visits the gynecology OPD with complaint of vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is a 3 x 3cm  growth involving cervix and upper part of vagina. Which of the following imaging would be most useful in staging and management of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI

  • Lymphangiography , CT, ultrasonography, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET) are used in an attempt to improve the accuracy of clinical staging
  • A systematic review,  comparing CT scan with MRI showed that MRI is significantly more sensitive with equivalent specificity. MRI has excellent sensitivity on T2 weighted images for detection of parametrial disease.

Other Options

  • Option A: An Ultrasound idoes not procide any additional information to aid in staginig of cervical cancer
  • Option B: CT scan: It is useful but an MRI is significantly more sensitive for detection of parametrial disease
  • Option D: As per FIGO 2018, the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources is permitted i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

Educational Objective:

Cervical cancer is primarily a clinical staging but FIGO 2018 staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

 

 

Ref : Berek and novak 16th edition, 2457

choices.text: Stage IA1 : microscopically detected carcinoma  ≤ 5 mm depth and ≤ 7mm extension
Stage IB1 : Cancer confined to cervix, lesion ≤ 4 cm in greatest dimension
Stage IB2: Cancer confined to cervix, lesion > 4 cm in greatest dimension
Stage IIA: Cervical carcinoma involving upper 2/3rd of vagina

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding staging of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stage IIA: Cervical carcinoma involving upper 2/3rd of vagina

Other Options can be ruled out by the staging of cervical cancer shown in the table below

Stage of cancer cervix (FIGO 2021)

Educational Objective:

Staging of cervical cancer is primarily a clinical staging and it is important to know this staging as shown in the table above

Ref: Berek and novak 16th edition, 2455

choices.text: Better disease eradication
Conservation of ovaries can be tried
Less bowel, bladder problems
Less sexual dysfunction

questions.text: Mrs Mala, a 40-year-old P2L2, underwent radical hysterectomy for cancer cervix.  Advantages of surgery over radiotherapy in treatment of cervical cancer are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A (better disease eradication)

The advantages of surgery over radiotherapy in treatment of cervical cancer are:

  • Spread of the disease can be determined more thoroughly by surgicopathological staging.
  • Surgery can assess the paraaortic and pelvic nodes and can better predict the survival rate
  • Preservation of ovarian function, if desired, specially in a young woman
  • Ovaries may be transposed out of the radiation field if radiation is considered in the postoperative period
  • Retention of more functional and pliable vagina for sexual function
  • Psychologic benefit to the patient in that her cancer bearing organ has been removed

 

Other Options: 

  • Option B: Conservation of ovaries can be tried in surgical management in young patients wanting fertility sparing as they can be transpositioned out of the radiation field if post op RT is planned
  • Option C: Less bowel bladder problems: Radiotherpay causes more bladder and bowel dysfunction as compared to surgery
  • Option D: Less sexual dysfunction: Radiotherapy causes more sexual dysfunction as it causes vaginal fibrosis

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16th edition 2470, 2487

DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, page 348

choices.text: Type 1 hysterectomy
Type 2 hysterectomy
Type 3 hysterectomy
Type 4 hysterectomy

questions.text: Mrs A, 56 year old woman, underwent Wertheim’s hysterectomy for cancer cervix. What type of hysterectomy is this :
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 hysterectomy 

  •  The hysterectomy described by Wertheim is less extensive than a radical hysterectomy and removes the medial half of the cardinal and uterosacral ligaments.
  • This procedure is often referred to as modified radical or type II hysterectomy.
  • Wertheim's original operation did not include pelvic lymphadenectomy but instead included selective removal of enlarged lymph nodes.
  • The modified radical hysterectomy (type II) differs from the radical hysterectomy (type III - also called as Meig Hysterectomy) in the following ways:
  1. The uterine artery is transected at the level of the ureter, thus preserving the ureteral branch to the ureter.
  2. The cardinal ligament is not divided near the sidewall but instead is divided close to its midportion near the ureteral dissection.
  3. The anterior vesicouterine ligament is divided, but the posterior vesicouterine ligament is conserved.
  4. A smaller margin of vagina is removed

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Type 1 hysterectomy is also called an extra-fasical hysterectomy and is done in non malignant or pre-malignant conditions. 
    • It involves ligation of the uterine artery, uterosacral and cardinal ligaments at the proximal part
    • vaginal cuff is not removed
  • Option C: A Type 3 hysterectomy is also called as Meig Hysterectomy
    • The cardinal ligament is divided near the sidewall (type 3) instead of close to its midportion near the ureteral dissection (type 2)
    • UTerosacral ligaments divided at their origin near the sacrum
    • A larger margin of vagina is removed in type 3 hysterectomy
    • Complete dissection of the ureter
    • Uterine artery divided at its origin
  • Option D: A type 4 hysterectomy is an extended radical hysterectomy where more parametrial and vaginal tissue is removed

Educational Objective: 

Types of hysterectomies:

  • A Type 1 hysterectomy is also called an extra-fasical hysterectomy and is done in non malignant or pre-malignant conditions. 
    • It involves ligation of the uterine artery, uterosacral and cardinal ligaments at the proximal part
    • No vaginal cuff is removed
  • A Type 2 hysterectomy (Wertheim hysterectomy)
    • Uterine arteries divided just medial to the ureter
    • Uterosacral ligaments divided midway
    • Cardinal ligaments divided midway
    • 2/3rd vaginal cuff is remove
  • Type 3- also called as Meig Hysterectomy
    • The cardinal ligament is divided near the sidewall (type 3) instead of close to its midportion near the ureteral dissection (type 2)
    • UTerosacral ligaments divided at their origin near the sacrum
    • A larger margin of vagina is removed in type 3 hysterectomy
    • Complete dissection of the ureter
    • Uterine artery divided at its origin
  • A Type 4 hysterectomy is an extended radical hysterectomy where more parametrial and vaginal tissue is removed
  • A type 5 hysterectomy involves partial exenteration. Part of the bladder and distal ureteral segments are also removed.  

 

 

Ref : Berek and Novak, 16th edition, page 2476

choices.text: Uterus+ cervix + upper 1/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + medial half of cardinal ligament
Uterus + cervix + upper 2/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + most of cardinal ligament
Uterus + cervix + upper 2/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + medial half of cardinal ligament
Uterus + cervix + upper 1/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + most of cardinal ligament

questions.text: Mrs Anita, a 70 year old woman has been counselled about radical hysterectomy and radiotherapy as treatment modalities for her cervcal cancer treatment. Meig’s Radical hysterectomy or type III hysterectomy involves removal of:
questions.solution:
Ans: B: 

  • Type 3 - also called as Meig Hysterectomy
    • The cardinal ligament is divided near the sidewall (type 3) instead of close to its midportion near the ureteral dissection (type 2)
    • Uterosacral ligaments divided at their origin near the sacrum
    • A larger margin of vagina is removed in type 3 hysterectomy (2/3rd) 
    • Complete dissection of the ureter
    • Uterine artery divided at its origin

Other Options

  • Option A: Uterus+ cervix + upper 1/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + medial half of cardinal ligament: This does not describe any of the radical hysterectomy types
  • Option C: Uterus + cervix + upper 2/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + medial half of cardinal ligament: This describes a type 2 hysterectomy
  • Option D: Uterus + cervix + upper 1/3rd of vagina + pelvic lymph nodes + most of cardinal ligament: This does not describe any of the radical hysterectomy types

Educational Objective: 

Types of hysterectomies:

  • A Type 1 hysterectomy is also called an extra-fasical hysterectomy and is done in non malignant or pre-malignant conditions. 
    • It involves ligation of the uterine artery, uterosacral and cardinal ligaments at the proximal part
    • No vaginal cuff is removed
  • A Type 2 hysterectomy (Wertheim hysterectomy)
    • Uterine arteries divided just medial to the ureter
    • Uterosacral ligaments divided midway
    • Cardinal ligaments divided midway
    • 2/3rd vaginal cuff is remove
  • Type 3- also called as Meig Hysterectomy
    • The cardinal ligament is divided near the sidewall (type 3) instead of close to its midportion near the ureteral dissection (type 2)
    • Uterosacral ligaments divided at their origin near the sacrum
    • A larger margin of vagina is removed in type 3 hysterectomy (2/3rd)
    • Complete dissection of the ureter
    • Uterine artery divided at its origin
  • A Type 4 hysterectomy is an extended radical hysterectomy where more parametrial and vaginal tissue is removed
  • A type 5 hysterectomy involves partial exenteration. Part of the bladder and distal ureteral segments are also removed

 

 

Ref : berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2476

choices.text: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with preservation of ovaries
Laparoscopic hysterectomy with transposition of ovaries
Radical trachelectomy
Simple trachelectomy

questions.text: Mrs Rina, a 35 year old P1L1 has 1.5 x 1.5cm growth limited to the cervix. A biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinomal of the cervix and an MRI reveals no other involvement of surrounding structures. She wishes to undergo fertility preserving surgery and future childbearing . Which of the following would be an appropriate management for her:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Radical trachelectomy.

  • Radical trachelectomy is a procedure that is gaining popularity as a surgical management option for women with stage 1A2 and IB1 disease who desire uterine preservation and fertility.
  • As this patient would fall into Stage 1 A2, this treatment modality can be offered
  • It is Suitable for tumors less than 2cm size.
  • In radical trachelectomy, the following is removed
    • The cervix
    • Part of parametria and paracolpos
    • Part of uterosacral ligaments
    • 1-2 cm of vaginal cuff
    • Descending cervico-vaginal branch of uterine artery is ligated
    • Permamant encerclage of the cervical stump 
    • Pelvic lymoh nodes

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with preservation of ovaries: This can also be considered in a woman wanting to preserve fertility but she will require a gestational surrogate
  • Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with transposition of ovaries: Transposition of the ovaris is usually done if the woman is to recieve pelvic radiotherapy
  • Option D: Simple trachelectomy is not an option in early stage cervical cancer. 

Educatiional Objective: 

Radical trachelectomy is a procedure that is gaining popularity as a surgical management option for women with stage 1A2 and IB1 disease who desire uterine preservation and fertility.

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition page 2473

choices.text: Stage IB3
Stage IIA1
Stage IIA2
Stage IIB

questions.text: Which of the following stage of cancer cervix would best be managed surgically?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stage IIA1

  • Early stage cervical cancers less than 4 cm can be surgically managed
  • Surgical management is preferred for Stages 1 - 2A
  • However, in large tumor sizes, radiation may be preferable

choices.text: Early age at first sexual intercourse
Nulliparity
Hormone replacement therapy
Family h/o breast cancer

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for her routine checkup. She reports no significant medical history and has been in good health. Her last pap smear was 5 years earlier and was normal. Her pelvic examination reveals a slightly enlarged cervix with a raised, friable lesion which bleeds on touch. A biopsy is performed, and histopathology confirms the presence of squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following risk factors is most strongly associated with the development of cervical squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Early age at first sexual intercourse

 

Explanation

 

Risk Factors for cervical cancer

  1. HPV (most important and also cause of cervical cancer)
  2. Early age at 1st intercourse
  3. Sexually transmitted diseases
  4. Early age at marriage
  5. Multiple births
  6. Low socio-economic status
  7. HIV +ve
  8. Multiple sexual partners
  9. Smoking
  10. Uncertain relation with Combined OCPs

Educational Objective:

  • Infection with HPV is the most important risk factor and also cause of cervical cancer

 

 

Ref: Page 338, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: HPV 6
HPV 16
HPV 18
HPV 31

questions.text: Which human papillomavirus (HPV) subtype is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma of the cervix?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. HPV 18

 

Explanation

  • HPV is the primary etiologic infectious agent associated with cervical cancer
  • High-risk HPV types include types 16, 18, 31, 33, 34, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 66, 68, and 70
  • Majority of cervical cancers are attributed to HPV 16 and 18
  • HPV 16 is more commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix
  • HPV 18 is a risk actor or cervical adenocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • Majority of cervical cancers are attributed to high risk HPV types 16 and 18

 

 

Ref: Page 684, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Lugol solution
Emergent radiation
Uterine artery embolization
Monsel (ferric subsulfate) solution

questions.text: A 54y woman presents to the OPD with post-menopausal bleeding. On a speculum examination, there is a fungating 4x3 cm growth seen arising from the cervix. A biopsy is taken but the patient starts profusely bleeding. Which of the following is not used for hemostasis in cases of life-threatening hemorrhage from suspected cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Lugol solution

 

Explanation

  • Cervical cancer typically bleeds on touch and sometimes can present with heavy bleeding or during an examination, torrential bleeding can start from the tumor bed
  • In such cases, bleeding can often be controlled with
    • Vaginal packing
    • Combination of Monsel paste (ferric subsulfate)
    • Topical acetone can also be used to obtain hemostasis, especially in cases refractory to Monsel paste
    • If bleeding continues, emergent radiation can be delivered.
    • Uterine artery or Internal iliac artery embolization or ligation can be performed in cases of refractory hemorrhage
       
  • Lugol’s iodine is not going to stop the bleeding. It is used as a test for cervical cancer screening

 

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical cancer typically bleeds on touch and sometimes can present with heavy bleeding or during an examination, torrential bleeding can start from the tumor bed
  • In such cases, bleeding can often be controlled with
    • Vaginal packing
    • Combination of Monsel paste (ferric subsulfate)
    • Topical acetone can also be used to obtain hemostasis, especially in cases refractory to Monsel paste
    • If bleeding continues, emergent radiation can be delivered.
    • Uterine artery or Internal iliac artery embolization or ligation can be performed in cases of refractory hemorrhage

 

 

Ref: Page 662, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Perform a pap smear
Perform a cervical biopsy
Refer to a gynecologic oncologist
Obtain a computed tomography (CT) scan

questions.text: A woman comes in for an annual gynecologic examination. During speculum examination, you see the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Perform a cervical biopsy.

 

Explanation:

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a lesion is seen, so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

Other options

  • A pap smear is done when there is no visible lesion on the cervix
  • Imaging studies and referral to a gyn oncologist have a role in cervical cancer once a diagnosis is made

Educational Objective:

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a lesion is seen, so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

 

 

Ref: Page no 663, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: IB2
IIB
IIIB
IVB

questions.text: A woman has a 6-cm adenocarcinoma of the cervix, positive para-aortic nodes found on positron emission tomography (PET) scan, and hydronephrosis. Based on these findings, which FIGO stage is she assigned?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IIIB

 

Explanation:

  • This is stage 3B due to the finding of hydronephrosis

FIGO Staging of cervical cancer (2021)

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical cancer staging is a clinical staging which is aided by imaging and pathology.

 

 

 Ref: Berek and Novak 16th edition, 2455

choices.text: A
B
C
Anywhere

questions.text: Which of the following arrows depicts where the uterosacral ligament is ligated during a type II radical hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. B

 

Explanation

 

Types of Hysterectomy

 

  • In this image, they have shown the utero-sacral ligaments and have asked about a type 2 hysterectomy; hence midway is the best answer

Educational Objective:

  • In a type 2 radical hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are ligated at the level of the ureter and the uterosacral ligaments are divided midway between the uterus and the sacrum
  • In a type 3 hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are ligated at the origin of the internal iliac vessels and the uterosacral ligaments are ligated near the sacrum

 

 

Ref: Page 171, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external os
5 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external os
2 cm lateral and 5 cm superior to the external os
5 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the internal os

questions.text: In brachytherapy for cervical cancer, how is point A defined?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external os

 

Explanation

 

Radiotherapy in cervical cancer

  • Both external beam pelvic radiation and brachytherapy are typically delivered
  • Of these, external beam radiation is usually given before intracavitary radiation (brachytherapy)
  • External beam radiation is commonly administered in 25 fractions during 5 weeks (40 to 50 Gy).
  • During brachytherapy, bowel and bladder are packed away from the intracavitary source using vaginal packing during tandem insertion to limit radiation to these organs.
  • Treatment is prescribed to
    • Point A: A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os; this point corresponds to the crossing of the uterine artery and ureter
    • Point B: which is a point 3 cm lateral to point A; this point corresponds to the lateral pelvic wall/ obturator lymph nodes

 

Educational Objective:

  • In cervical cancer, radiotherapy (brachytherapy) is prescribed to 2 points
  • Treatment is prescribed to
    • Point A: A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os; this point corresponds to the crossing of the uterine artery and ureter
    • Point B: which is a point 3 cm lateral to point A; this point corresponds to the lateral pelvic wall/ obturator lymph nodes

 

 

Ref: page 672, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Radiation alone
Chemotherapy
Total pelvic exenteration
Radiation with concomitant chemotherapy

questions.text: If a patient with stage IB1 squamous cell carcinoma recurs at the vagina after a radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection, what is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Radiation with concomitant chemotherapy

 

Explanation

  • The given scenario is of a recurrence
  • Risk factors for recurrent disease are:
    • Large tumor size
    • Lymph vascular space invasion
    • Positive lymph nodes
    • Advanced stage disease
       
  • Most common site of recurrence is the pelvic side wall.
  • Features of disease recurrence are: Pain in the pelvis, back, unilateral leg edema, ureteral obstruction, vaginal bleeding, palpable tumor in the pelvis and lymphadenopathy.
  • Treatment of recurrence:
    • Single agent or multiagent chemotherapy with cisplatin, paclitaxel or ifosfamide is used along with Radiation therapy may be used to those who have been treated initially with surgery.
       

Educational Objective:

  • Treatment of recurrence of cervical cancer:
    • Single agent or multiagent chemotherapy with cisplatin, paclitaxel or ifosfamide is used along with Radiation therapy may be used to those who have been treated initially with surgery.

 

 

Ref: Page 354, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
